conversation.content: [stern] Never thought I'd see you three hundred feet up in the air working on, [bitter], anything mechanical after you said my trade was dying.
[defensive] Dad, please.

[frustrated] This bearing assembly is the same principle I taught you when you were, [shaky voice], twelve in the shop but you wouldn't listen because traditional machining wasn't, [condescending], green enough for you. [sigh]
[anxious] Well, um, I mean, the thing is these turbines require, [hesitantly], specialized training that goes beyond just, er, basic mechanical work, you know?
[loudly] Um, specialized training doesn't mean much when the, [angry], gearbox is seized and you've been up here for, umm, three hours without fixing it, does it? [groan]
[very quietly] The diagnostic software says it's an electrical fault but the, [confused], symptoms don't match anything in our manual. [pause]
[mocking] Software can't feel metal fatigue or hear when a, [passionate], bearing is crying for help the way someone who's spent forty years, [slowly], listening to machines can.

[embarrassed] You're saying this whole shutdown is just a, [whispering], mechanical failure that our million-dollar monitoring system, [desperate], completely missed because we rely too much on computers?

[confidently] Hand me that wrench and I'll show you how the vibration pattern tells us it's, [warm], not electrical at all but a simple misalignment that's been, [quickly], cascading through the drivetrain for weeks.
[curious] Well, er, how could you possibly know that without, umm, even running a diagnostic check first?

[gently] Because your fancy turbine is still just gears and bearings and shafts, [proud], the same fundamentals I've been machining since before you were born, and metal, [very sincerely], always tells the truth if you know how to listen. [chuckle]
[amazed] The pitch of that whine changes exactly where you said the, [relieved], misalignment would be worst.
You know, um, maybe if we worked together instead of, [regretful], fighting about old versus new technology, we could, well, actually solve this faster. [cough]
[appreciative] Um, yeah, I mean, okay.
[excited] See that scoring pattern on the shaft tells us the whole story of what happened, [animated], just like reading a book written in metal, [cheerful], if you know the language. [laugh]

I spent so many years thinking your work was, [ashamed], obsolete but watching you diagnose this in minutes when our team couldn't fix it in, [admiring], hours makes me realize how much I still need to, er, learn from you.
[soft-spoken] Not obsolete, son.

[emotional] The way you touch that metal and immediately know what's wrong is something no, [respectful], computer program could ever replace and I was too, [trembling], stubborn to see it before today.
[warm] These renewable energy machines you work on are the future and I'm, [very proud], proud you're part of that even if I don't understand all the electronics.

[hopeful] Maybe you could teach me the old-school diagnostics while I show you the, [enthusiastic], turbine control systems because we make a pretty good team when we're not, [joking], arguing about everything. [laugh loudly]
